title: MARKET REPORT: Investors in peer-to-peer lender Funding Circle breath sigh of relief
text:
Investors in peer-to-peer lender Funding Circle breathed a sigh of relief after the group released a rare piece of good news.

Its loans under management reached a record £3.7 billion in the past three months, up by almost a third on the same period last year.

The company, which provides funds to small firms by connecting them with private and institutional investors through an online platform, also said it has written £1.8 billion worth of new loans so far in 2019, up 9 per cent on last year.

Funding Circle has had a turbulent first year as a listed company – with complaints from investors about its processes exacerbated by warnings from City watchdog the Financial Conduct Authority that it is planning a crackdown on the peer-to-peer lending industry.

Its stock jumped 16.9 per cent, or 17.4p, to 120.4p last night, but is still down 73 per cent from when it listed last October at 440p.

Middle East-focused healthcare group NMC Health initially rallied on a bullish update from its capital markets day – an event where investors are invited to meet management and get detailed updates about its strategy.

NMC forecast a better performance in the second half of this year, double-digit revenue growth in 2020 and pointed out it has strengthened its corporate governance with the new role of a group compliance officer and two additional committees. Despite the update, shares in the private hospital group shed 1.7 per cent, or 44p, to 2606p.

Pearson shares were unmoved by an upgrade from brokers at Deutsche Bank, who upgraded the stock to 'hold' from 'sell' and said a huge recent sell-off in its shares 'seems to be over'.

The education publisher warned on profits last month, amid a tricky restructuring that is seeing it shift from textbooks to digital products and services. Shares closed flat at 674.6p.

FTSE 250-listed Micro Focus fell 6.9 per cent, or 75.2p, to a 19-month low of 1012.4p after a Canadian firm, Open Text, poured cold water over rumours that it was looking to buy the British IT giant.

Open Text denied a Bloomberg report last week that it was mulling a bid for Micro Focus, which is still struggling from the fallout of a merger with HP's software business for £6.6 billion in 2017. The acquisition included HP's troubled Autonomy arm, which is still wading through a fraud trial between HP and Autonomy's founders.

Despite Micro Focus's plunge, the wider FTSE 250 index finished the day 0.4 per cent higher, up 80.26 points, at 20308.79 on hopes the UK will avoid a No Deal Brexit.

The exporter-heavy FTSE 100 rose 0.2 per cent, or 13.07 points, to 7163.64. It was kept out of the red by rises in some of the index's biggest mining companies, which edged higher as they tracked a boost in copper prices triggered by unrest in top producing country Chile. Riots have swept the capital Santiago and other cities, while there have also been strikes at mines.

Anglo American gained 2.1 per cent, or 40p, to 1939.8p, Rio Tinto added 1 per cent, or 37.5p, to 3999p, while over on the FTSE 250, Kaz Minerals rose 3.3 per cent, or 14.2p, to 448.3p.

On the junior AIM market, online clothing retailer Koovs was pummelled after the Indian central bank intervened in an investment by the company's largest shareholder, Future Group, and demanded that Future reapply for approval. Koovs warned the investment, for £6.8m worth of shares, may not complete by the end of this year. Its stock sank 37.3 per cent, or 1.9p, to 3.2p.

There was no fanfare for private investor favourite Angling Direct as it opened its 32nd store and said it will open several more over the next few months.

Shares in the fishing tackle retailer were flat at 61.5p.
